awd_titl_txt: Non-Destructive Evaluation of Additively Manufactured Parts via Impedance-Based Measurements
awd_abstract_narration:
There has been a significant increase in the desire to use Additive Manufacturing technologies for the realization of end-use products due to their ability to produce complex geometries that can be tailored to improve system performance.  However, broad industrial adoption of Additive Manufacturing has been constrained due to the limitations of currently available non-destructive evaluation technologies, which stymie validation of process performance. To address this need, the research team will explore a non-destructive evaluation technique that uses piezoelectric materials as collocated sensors and actuators to simultaneously excite a printed part and measure its dynamic response. Due to the coupled electromechanical characteristics of piezoelectric materials, the measured electrical impedance depends on the characteristics of the printed part (inertia, stiffness and damping). Therefore, changes induced by printing defects are reflected on the measured electrical impedance, and hence, can readily be detected. This award supports fundamental research to gain an understanding of how part and defect parameters affect the researched non-destructive evaluation process' detection resolution and range. The team has created a well-formulated plan to integrate the central concepts of this research into the summer camp activities offered by Virginia Tech's Center for the Enhancement of Engineering Diversity (CEED). The integration of the research into hands-on laboratory experiences for CEED's underrepresented students will contribute to the development of human resources and seeks to broaden interest in STEM careers related to advanced manufacturing.  

The primary objectives of this research are (i) to explore how the sensitivity of the impedance-based process is affected by part material and defect type, size, and location, and (ii) to conduct an analysis of the resulting impedance responses to enable identification of defect type. Parts featuring designed defects of various sizes, types (dimensional inaccuracies, positional inaccuracies, and internal porosity), and locations will be fabricated from multiple additive manufacturing processes (polymer extrusion, polymer powder bed fusion, and metal powder bed fusion). The measured impedance-based responses will be compared against baseline responses obtained from defect-free control samples via formulation of the composite damage metric as a multivariable optimization problem, which will enable the team to understand sources of variation in the impedance-based technique's sensitivity. The outcomes of this project include (i) a non-destructive evaluation process for efficiently validating additively manufactured parts and identifying embedded defects; (ii) an understanding of how impedance-based measurements are affected by excitation frequency, part material, and defect topology; (iii) an understanding of how impedance response corresponds to common additive manufacturing defect types; and (iv) a novel composite damage metric and framework for impedance-based defect identification.  In this regard, this outcomes of this project will have significant impact on both Additive Manufacturing and Structural Health Monitoring communities.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.inst_name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

por.por_cntn:
This project sought to characterize Impedance-based Nondestructive Evaluation for Additive Manufacturing (INDEAM): a quality control approach addressing challenges unique to the validation and certification of additively manufactured (AM) parts. In essence, the complexity characteristic of additive manufacturing combined with a phase-change of the feedstock during fabrication complicate the application of conventional nondestructive evaluation (NE) techniques by limiting direct access for measurement probes to surfaces and permitting the introduction of internal defects that are not present in the feedstock. NE approaches that are capable of surmounting these challenges (i.e., CT scanning) are expensive and time consuming. 

Impedance-based evaluation relies on the fact that the vibrational properties of a structure yield insight into its material properties and geometry—the same fact that already enables model validation of structures from helicopters to satellites. Impedance-based evaluation, though, simplifies and economizes conventional experiments by using piezoelectric wafers bonded to a part to both excite and measure its dynamic response. Electromechanical coupling encodes the vibrational properties of the part in the electrical impedance of the bonded wafer. In the context of structural health monitoring (SHM)—the practice of comparing measurements of a structure over time to detect deterioration—impedance measurements have been a subject of literature since the 90s. INDEAM generalizes the structure-to-itself comparisons characteristic of the SHM process through introduction of inter-part comparisons: instead of comparing a structure to itself over time, potentially-damaged structures are compared to known-healthy references. At the start of this project the use of high-frequency dynamic response characteristics for inter-part comparisons was limited to a proprietary technique known as process compensated resonance testing.  However, the technique does not combine actuator and sensor, it uses a proprietary method for analysis, and existing literature appears focused on extremely stiff, geometrically simple, machined components. 

The work done herein addresses the challenges with using impedance measurements to characterize a broader range of materials, manufacturing processes, and methods of instrumentation. In the context of AM, the application of impedance-based evaluation is further complicated by a higher level of variation in fabricated parts, increased surface roughness, and the desire to inspect more highly damped plastics. As laid out in the proposal, we experimented with the use of INDEAM to examine parts produced through a variety of processes and materials. These include polymer parts in nylon via fused-filament fabrication and powder bed fusion processes, titanium parts via electron beam melting and aluminum parts via direct metal laser sintering. These experiments helped us understand the approximate scales and types of defects detectable and revealed considerations for measurement of parts fabricated in these different materials. However, as we applied this technique to larger sets of samples it was found that these techniques were hindered by the larger amount of variance seen in inter-part comparisons. Thus, without improvements to the process, the technique would likely not be sufficient to confidently detect defects on the scales relevant to most inspection of AM parts. 

Ultimately, the level of variation in measurements of control parts—as quantified by the metrics commonly used in the field—prohibited robust discrimination between control parts and parts containing defects of reasonable size. Thus, a significant amount of the work presented here discusses the means by which we might reduce the variation measured. First was a novel method to conduct impedance-based evaluation through an instrumented clamp attached to the part. This method demonstrated that the variation in piezoelectric wafers and bonding-layer characteristics could be mitigated while maintaining the ability to sense changes. Second was the application of model reduction techniques and modal analysis tools to the problem of impedance-based evaluation. The reframed problem permits more and different information to be extracted from measurements, proposes means to limit reliance on experimenter expertise, and carefully cut away information in the signature that is irrelevant to the part structure. And third, we demonstrated how the sources of variation in impedance measurements can be separated and studied. The process described allows identification of the most significant contributions to the variation in the measurement, so that efforts to improve the process can be accurately targeted.

The several novel tools and applications discussed above address specific challenges in the field of impedance-based evaluation that have hindered statistically confident identification of damage. By examining the assumptions of impedance-based evaluation and carefully reviewing the process by which it is carried out, this work provides a framework for improving the technique and eventually enabling its adoption as an accepted method of qualification for AM. The student who carried out this research has earned his doctorate as a result. The student has presented his work at various international conferences, and additional portions of the work are in preparation as journal articles. The student also benefited through mentoring both an undergraduate and graduate student. And, this research enabled opportunities to work with outside corporate and scientific entities who are interested in the work being done. 


Last Modified: 01/20/2021
Modified by: Pablo Tarazaga
